I get scoffed at and ridiculed for my belief in a recent creation. But unlike Darwinists' faith in beneficial random mutations, my belief is based on more than blind faith. There is some stunning evidence out there for people who want to look into it. The truth is, science and the media effectively supresses, denies, hides and lies about any detail, any fragment that hints to the fact that things didn't happen the way they say they happend.
 
 So here's an overview of what I think may have happened. Please keep in mind that I simply cannot put in this post the mountains of evidence that's out there, but this will be a start. First of all, I would like you to hold in your head what I said before: that science supresses any and all information that points away from long ages, uniformatarianism, reductionism and evolution.
 -----------------------------------------------------
 
 
 I believe it's quite possible that the world was initially created much smaller than it is today, and much like mars, there were no oceans. The Bible says there was a fermament in the early days and that at some point the land masses were separated by the waters that came from the "fountains of the deep." My theory is that sometime after the floods came, the earth cracked open, and the continents became separated sometime after that, leaving the oceans (some of these flood waters) in between. In short, the earth grew, much like a balloon expands, which separated the people, plants and animals.

Either that or we had some ancient-history sailors, floating across the Atlantic and Pacific oceans -- and lots of them.
 
 Not only that, but science doesn't tell people that there have been ancient indian sites in the Americas uncovered, which the strata dates back to between 300,000 and 400,000 years....this would put the American Indian alive and well at the same time as the oldest Neanderthals in Europe.

But what many people may not know is that on the American continent 10,000 years ago there were also giant bears, giant camels, giant beavers (the size of a bear) giant dragon flies, giant alligators, giant elephants, sloth, bison, and many many more megafauna. Doesn't it make sense that all the large mammals lived at the same time as the large lizards???  And isn't it strange that there are completely fossilized African-type negoid skull uncovered in South America dated at 11,000 years ago? How strange that this didn't make headline news!! Did these people paddle thousands of miles over the Atlantic Ocean on their canoes? 
 
 http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50B1EFD3F5C0C758EDDA90994D1494D81
 
 DISPLAYING ABSTRACT - Fossilized skull displayed at National Museum in Rio de Janeiro after two decades in storage has now been identified by Brazilian scientists as oldest human remains ever recovered in Western Hemisphere; is that of young woman, nicknamed Luzia, who is believed to have roamed savannah of south-central Brazil some 11,500 years ago; her features appear to be Negroid rather than Mongoloid, suggesting that Western Hemisphere may have initially been settled not only earlier than thought, but by people distinct from ancestors of today's North and South American Indian of Dr Walter Neves with Luzia's skull
 
 So we have Africans living in South America just a few thousand years ago. Who knew?
 
 
 Not only that, but if a human skull can completely fossilize in 11,000 years (or less), what does that tell us about the fact that dinosaur bones are fossilized? You got it - jack squat. Of course Scientists will date dinosaurs by the "strata" their bones are found in....but what "strata" is laying on top of the ground??? And why did American Indians write so many stories about interacting with dinosaurs? Why did they draw them on cave walls? Why are dinosaur depicted on pottery? How are unfossilized dinosaur bones found laying on top of the ground in Alaska? How are dinosaurs sculpted into walls in Ethiopia? How is dinosaur soft tissue still around after 65 - 200 million years?

So my contention is that all the continents may have been together in the not-so-distant past. If all the continents were together, and there were no oceans...then that would mean that there probably were no ice caps....(since it takes large volumes of water to make that much ice)...also, as some have suggested their may have been a "mist" or some sort of water canopy around the earth, which would keep the earth warm and humid from pole to pole.
 
 Of course we know that animals roamed on all continents. Recently some dinosaur bones were found on antarctica....so whenever the dinosaurs roamed was obviously a warm climate, not a frigid ice box....and obviously the dinosaurs had the GET there, so the continents had to be together. So the question is, WHEN did antarctica freeze over....? If antarctica was not frozen over several thousand years ago, and animals/humans roamed there, then it would make sense that it may not have been in its current position.

 Hmmm.
 
 Ok, look, I'll deal with this as seriously as I know how. 
 
 First of all, the Pangea theory already puts the continents together in a single lump, yes? So most of the congruencies between the edges of continents are not particularly controversial. The extra ones he's postulating - well, there are some pretty serious contortions involved and no very good reason for accepting them.
 
 However, that's not my biggest problem. These are:
 
 Oceans cover 71% of the earth's surface. To create a sphere with only 29% of the surface area you would have to shrink the earth to around half its present diameter, reducing its mass to only 15% of what it is now and causing some unfortunate side effects like losing all our atmosphere and the moon. In addition, none of our fossil evidence would make sense because it's all of a proportion to withstand one standard G, not 0.15G.
 
 More seriously, there's the geometric changes involved. The animation shows all the continents sliding peacefully away from one another - however, consider the continent of Africa. On the earth as it is today, it covers almost seventy degrees of arc in both directions. On an earth half the size it would cover almost a hundred and forty - pretty near spanning a whole hemisphere. 
 
 The easiest way to demonstrate why this would be a problem is for you to go get a kid's minature football (soccer ball, if you insist) and a basket ball. Cut a roughly Africa-shaped patch out of the soccer ball, covering about 140 degrees side to side and top to bottom, and try to paste it onto the surface of the basketball. I'm sure just thinking about it you can see why it's not going to work: the sharper curvature forces it up in the middle, and the only way to get around that is to make cuts in from the edges to allow them to spread out. We can even calculate how much: a shape subtending 70 degrees on a full-size sphere has (roughly) a 14% longer perimeter than a shape subtending 140 degrees on a half-size sphere. Yet Africa has almost no major rivers leading into its heart; no indication of geological 'stretch marks' whatsoever. 
 
 It's a fun idea, but totally, totally barmy :)

Go to IIDB and take a look at his very first thread. Right out of the gate, he was hurling accusations of deception and conspiracy, complete with blatant misrepresentation and obvious ignorance of the subject matter. IIDBers really have very little patience for drive-bys, but a significant number of them tried some helpful comments (e.g. "natural selection is not random"). SS didn't even make it through the first page before making the positive accusation of fraud. 
 His second thread -- which actually was simultaneous (an early indicator of his typical impending spam) -- was even better. He had a great number of people responding with information, but supersport continued ignoring major points and responding with nothing but distractions.
 Notice that there were countless calls in both threads for evidence instead of mere assertion. Several people expressed genuine curiosity at the absolute strangeness of his claims -- which of course weren't helped by the lack of actual evidence. He never gave a cogent explanation of his argument. What links he did provide during his tenure there were ones that refuted his points instead of supported them. And of course, there were the repeated mentions of butterfly wombs...

Either way, if intolerance and antagonism is his justification for carpet-bombing this forum and others, it might be worth a try defusing the situation rather than feeding it.
 
 Just a thought :)

As we all know, science has admitted that the continents were all together at some point in the past. The breakup of Pangea supposedly happened some 100 million years ago -- long before monkeys supposedly evolved. And monkeys have been said to originate in Africa some 30 million years ago. So my question is, how did the monkeys get to South America? Did they wander up through the blizzards of Northern Russia and hike/swim across the Bering strait? (There's not one shred of evidence of this)... Did they sail across the Atlantic Ocean?

Actually, the separation of Africa and South America happened much later than you claim. It happened in the late Cretaceous. You are also quite sloppy in your use of the word "monkey." Perhaps African monkeys evolved only 30 million years ago, but certainly primates from which the monkeys evolved are much older. That's why South American monkeys and African monkeys are so different.
 
 A better question would be how those monkeys got to South America from the ark that was at the top of a mountain in Turkey. Did Noah drop them off on the way or did they build boats and sail across the Atlantic?
